node.title: Manuel Neri, Figurative Sculptor With a Modern Twist, Dies at 91
node.alt: The artist Manuel Neri pictured in 1982 with some of his painted statues. Mr. Neri flourished as part of the Bay Area Figurative Movement of artists in the 1950s and â€™60s.
node.description: Mr. Neri was a stalwart of the Bay Area art scene but exhibited widely, known for mixing artistic mediums and styles.
node.content: ["Manuel Neri, a noted San Francisco artist whose life-size figurative sculptures, often painted and usually of women, evoked classical statuary while updating it for the 20th century, died on Oct. 18 at his home in Sacramento. He was 91.", "His death was confirmed by his daughter, the artist Ruby Neri.", "Mr. Neri was a younger presence in the Bay Area Figurative Movement, which encompassed a group of artists in the 1950s and \u201960s who bucked the trend toward Abstract Expressionism and returned to figure-focused art. Its members included the painters Richard Diebenkorn and David Park and the sculptor and ceramicist Peter Voulkos. Mr. Neri studied with Mr. Diebenkorn and Mr. Voulkos, among others in the movement.", "In plaster, bronze and other materials, Mr. Neri rendered figures sometimes without heads or arms and painted directly on the casts, incorporating scratched or textured detailing. His oeuvre centered on the female form; the poet Mary Julia Klimenko was his model for much of his career.", "\u201cWhat distinguishes Mr. Neri\u2019s art is the way he has combined the traditional nude figure, executed in plaster, bronze and stone, with the interests \u2014 including the color interests \u2014 of painting,\u201d the New York Times critic Hilton Kramer wrote in 1981 on the occasion of Mr. Neri\u2019s his first solo exhibition, at the Cowles Gallery in Manhattan.", "\u201cThere is thus an extraordinary tension \u2014 or, if you will, a dialectic \u2014 built into the very crux of his style,\u201d Mr. Kramer continued. \u201cThis gives the work a very individual dynamism, even if at times it also leaves us with the impression of something teetering on the brink of dissolution.\u201d", "In a 2008 oral history with the Smithsonian Archives of American Art, Mr. Neri said, \u201cI\u2019ve always been fascinated by body language that people have, what they say with their bodies.\u201d", "His sculpture could have a destructive edge, the missing limbs and torsos evoking the remains of Greek and Roman statuary, damaged over time, seen in museums. But textured surfaces and blotches of bright color updated Mr. Neri\u2019s work for the 20th century (though the application of color also harked back to the painted sculpture of antiquity).", "Mr. Neri was part of the lively Beat scene in San Francisco in the 1950s and early \u201960s. In 1954 he and a group of other artists established the Six Gallery, housed in a former automobile repair shop on Fillmore Street. Mr. Neri was the director of the gallery when a landmark poetry reading took place there in 1955: Allen Ginsburg giving the first public recitation of his masterpiece, \u201cHowl.\u201d", "Mr. Neri was one of the few Latinos in the American mainstream art world of the time. But, as he said in the oral history, he did not necessarily \u201cconnect\u201d with the label of Latino art: He situated his work more in the context of the Bay Area, where he made his home.", "\u201cI step out of one world into another,\u201d he said. \u201cI had to make that change, but that flavoring, that Latino flavoring, will always be with me.\u201d", "Manuel John Neri Jr. was born in Sanger, Calif., in Fresno County, on April 12, 1930. His father was an agricultural worker. His mother, Guadalupe (Penilla) Neri, also worked in agriculture and was later employed at an electronics factory. Both parents were immigrants from the Mexican state of Jalisco.", "Mr. Neri attended Fremont High School and graduated in 1950. He then signed up for classes at San Francisco City College.", "\u201cAnd just out of dumb luck, I decided to take an art class for an easy grade,\u201d he recalled. \u201cAnd I met a wonderful man who changed my life.\u201d That man was the artist Roy Walker, who introduced him to Mr. Voulkos and gave him entree to the San Francisco art scene.", "Mr. Neri went on to attend the University of California, Berkeley, and what is now the California College of Arts. He served in the Army in the Korean War and then studied at the California School of Fine Arts (now the San Francisco Art Institute) on the G.I. Bill. But he never completed a degree.", "From 1959 on, Mr. Neri taught at schools around the Bay Area and later at Berkeley. He joined the art faculty at the University of California, Davis, in 1965 and held a teaching post there until retiring in 1990.", "For many years he worked and lived in the Bay Area city of Benicia in a former Unitarian church, which he remodeled into a home and studio.", "His marriages to Marilyn Hampton, the artist Joan Brown, Susan Morse and Kate Rohrock ended in divorce.", "Mr. Neri received numerous accolades for his work, including the Lifetime Achievement Award from the International Sculpture Center in Hamilton, N.J., in 2006. His works are in the collections of the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington.", "He is survived by his sister, Maria Clowser; his caretaker, Maria Elisa Cantu; his children Raoul Neri, Laticia Souter, Noel Neri, Maximilian Neri, Ruby Neri, Julia Leonard and Gustavo Neri; and seven grandchildren."]
